result.execSummary:
The defendant Richard F. Rau was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Richard F. Rau is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Richard F. Rau was found guilty of OWI (5th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent to any current sentence.  Defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program but is eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.  Defendant shall receive 57 days credit for time served.  Defendant currently in custody at the Winnebago County Jail.

superMiscConds.notes: If extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. Clerk of Courts shall docket without fees. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
No use or possession of controlled substances, unless prescribed by a physician; no possession of drug paraphernalia and no possession/consumption of intoxicants.

Complete compas assessment,  counseling, evaluations, programs and assessments as appropriate and followup.  Pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections and follow rules of supervision.

Maintain absolute sobriety and continue with AODA after-care treatment.

Defendant shall provide a DNA sample by CALLING the Winnebago County Jail, Work Release Unit, WITHIN 72 HOURS, to set up an appointment during the hours of 8:00 a.m. - 4:00. p.m. Monday through Friday, at 920-232-1915 or 920-232-1919.  Defendant shall provide proof of identification along with the court minutes stating a DNA sample is required.  Failure to comply with this order may result in either a finding of contempt of court or a criminal charge of Failure to Provide a DNA Sample pursuant to Wis. Stats., 946.52.
Undertake AODA assessment and comply with treatment recommendations.

supervisions.notes: IID requirement applies to all vehicles which are registered in your name and any vehicles you operate.  During your IID requirement period, you may not operate any motor vehicle without an IID installed.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea
